article_title: Here’s what Ontario’s premier candidates are promising for small businesses
article_text:
As Ontario gets set to go to the polls this week, small business owners are looking for some promises that will help their companies stay in business and grow; and in turn help build a stronger economy.

In a recent survey, the candidates for premier of Ontario — Liberal Party leader and Premier Kathleen Wynne, Progressive Conservative leader Tim Hudak, New Democratic Party leader Andrea Horwath and Green Party leader Mike Schreiner — weigh in on what they would do to help the province’s small businesses if they were elected.

Minimum Wage and Pension Plans Do you plan to further increase the minimum wage (beyond $11.00/hour)? PC: Not at this time, no. Liberals: We will link future increases to the Consumer Price Index to provide small business with the predictability they need to plan for their future. NDP: Yes, we plan to phase in a $12/hr. minimum wage over two years combined with a similarly phased in reduction in the small business tax from 4.5% to 3%. Green: The GPO would gradually raise the minimum wage to $12 an hour and index it to inflation. Do you support or oppose the implementation of the proposed Ontario Retirement Pension Plan? PC: We strongly oppose it. I agree with small businesses that affordable and portable Pooled Registered Pension Plans are a great opportunity. Liberals: We support the ORPP to help ensure that Ontarians have the secure retirement that they need and deserve. NDP: If it becomes clear that there will be no federal support for a CPP enhancement, an Ontario NDP government will implement an Ontario Pension Plan. Green: The Green Party supports pension reforms to ensure that all Ontarians have adequate financial resources to retire with dignity. We believe such reforms are best made at the federal level.

The Canadian Federation of Independent Business recently asked each of the four candidates how they would deal with issues that affect Ontario’s small businesses, including tackling red tape, addressing high energy prices and their stance on taxes.

Ontario has some 372,000 employer businesses, with small firms (those with fewer than 100 employees) making up about 98% of those businesses. Issues such as bureaucratic burden and Ontario’s high energy prices have been a particular challenge for entrepreneurs in the province — topics that are rarely discussed in the context of small businesses.

“We surveyed our members recently and they felt small business issues have not been discussed thoroughly in this campaign,” said Plamen Petkov, vice-president of CFIB Ontario. “So this is a chance to get the candidates on record about where they stand on topics that affect small business owners in Ontario.”

Below, each of the candidates present their answers on how they would help small businesses in the province:

PCs Mr. Hudak, whose platform focuses on his Million Jobs Plan, said his government would help small businesses in the province by cutting taxes and implementing spending cut recommendations made by Don Drummond, former chief economist at TD Bank.

“We will lower [taxes], first by replacing corporate welfare with fair and lower taxes for all job creators, and then by reducing income taxes after the budget is balanced,” Mr. Hudak said. “We will abolish the College of Trades and its new trades tax, end eco taxes, repeal WSIB Bill 119, and we will not proceed with massive new payroll taxes for a new government pension scheme.” WSIB Bill 119 made it mandatory for most construction workers to have coverage starting Jan. 1, 2013.

Mr. Hudak added that he expects to have the provincial budget balanced by 2016, following the guidelines made in the Drummond Report. Those recommendations include freezing wages for every government worker, shrinking cabinet, lowering spending in every area of government but health care, reducing the size of the government payroll by 100,000 positions to 2009 levels, bringing balance back to benefits for government workers, alternative service delivery and comprehensive arbitration reform.

Liberals Ms. Wynne said her government would help reduce red tape by renewing the Open for Business initiative and introducing the “Better Business Climate Act,” which would require government to report annually on regulatory burden reduction.

In addition, she said, the Liberals would launch the Five-Point Business Energy Savings Plan, which would provide small businesses with “the tools they need to understand their bills, conserve energy, manage costs and save money.”

Ms Wynne said the Liberals plan to balance the budget by 2017-18 and would not increase taxes on small business, maintaining the corporate income tax rate for small businesses at 4.5%.

She added that the Liberals would raise the Employer Health Tax Exemption from $400,000 to $450,000 of annual Ontario payroll Harmonized Sales Tax, saying it would “save businesses $4.6-billion a year through input tax credits.”

Her party would also eliminate the Capital Tax, which she expects will save businesses more than $2.1-billion a year. Finally, Ms. Wynne said she would bring in enhanced tax credit rates to small businesses for employee training and would extend the Accelerated Capital Cost Allowance to 2015, cutting taxes by $265-million by 2016.

Related

NDP Ms. Horwath said her platform sees small businesses as being a core part of creating new jobs in Ontario.

“We are putting forward an ambitious program that includes a two-year phase-in of a 1.5% reduction in the small business rate from 4.5% to 3%,” Ms. Horwath said. “The Ontario NDP is also proposing a Job Creator Tax Credit that will provide a $5,000 tax credit for each new job created by an eligible business.”

Ms. Horwath also said that the NDP would help lower energy costs in Ontario by merging four of Ontario’s hydro agencies and capping their CEOs’ salaries.

“We will also get a better price for electricity exports through direct trading and take the HST off home heating bills,” Ms. Horwath said. “We need a government that can stand up for families and deliver on lower energy costs.”

Ms. Horwath added that the Ontario NDP will balance the budget by 2017-18 by “saving $600-million with a Minister of Savings and Accountability, stopping corporate tax giveaways and closing loopholes, toughening up rules on government partisan advertising and appointing a financial accountability officer to stop waste before it happens.”

Green Party Mr. Schreiner, co-founder of WOW Foods, an award winning local organic food distribution company and Earthdance Organics, a Guelph-based food production business that supplied area health foods stores and farmer’s markets in the early 2000s, understands the challenges small businesses face.

“The Green Party of Ontario recognizes the essential contributions to our economy and job-creating ability of small businesses,” he said. “I’m a small business owner who doesn’t think the political status quo is working.”

Mr. Schreiner said the Green Party will lower payroll taxes by doubling the Employer Health Tax exemption from $450,000 to $900,000 for small business with payrolls of less than $5-million.

“This will put up to $18,000 per year in your register to help grow your business,” he said.

Money for the new exemptions will come from raising Ontario’s corporate income tax rate to 12.5%, reversing the 1% cut made by the Liberals, said Mr. Schreiner. He also said he would work with small businesses to reform the Workplace Safety and Insurance Board.
